comments.commentBody: I don't subscribe to the "if you don't have anything good to say, don't say anything at all" theory. Sometimes it's appropriate, even necessary, to say things that are not nice. However, prefacing your comment with "I know this is a horrible thing to say," should certainly put up a red flag. And, that's especially true when what you're going to go on to say is purely speculative about the motives and sentiments of a person you don't know intimately and is motivated by a clear desire to characterize the target of your comments as "not one of us." (Fortunately, it's impossible to construe Giuliani's comment as racist because, as Giuliani helpfully pointed out, it can't be racist to say things like this about a person who was "raised by a white mother!!!!)

Truth is not always pretty. The time has passed for niceties. There is too much at stake in the world now to stand on ceremony, nit-pick about word choice or style or worry about the out-of-touch sensibilities of hypocrites and schoolmarms. Substance and honesty are all that matter now, and on that account, Giuliani hit the nail on the head, and rather too politely in my view. How refreshing to hear a politician honestly speak his mind if only a smidgeon before the pc media police pounce.
Just remember that Alice Longworth Roosevelt (Teddy's daughter) once said that "if you don't have anything good to say about someone, just tell me."

Curious that Giuliani would preface his offensive remarks by saying he knew it was a terrible thing to say.  My mother could have taught him that if he didn't have anything good to say, not to say anything at all.  Clearly, he was not brought up the way you and I were.

I have the same feeling.. Mayor 9-11 was an expert in fanning racial flames during his tenure. He has probably decided that the events in Ferguson and Staten Island , among others, give him a  chance to return as "Law&Order Rudy." Bob McCulloch would  be a great VP choice! The Republican primary will provide a national test of the gag reflex.

It seems to me that with this imbecilic and scurrilous diatribe Mr. Giuliani is revealing that he plans to make another run at his Party's presidential nomination.  The Kochs and the Adelsons are already writing out their checks.

Well spoken! I cannot agree more with you. If Rudi showed leadership on 9/11, Obama has showed real leadership with a collapsed economy with several wars and still managed to remain cool. This guy is the only sane politician in America today. God bless him.

I agree with Vance in that Obama will be remembered more positively in the future than he is appreciated now.  He has presided over a country in such a state of disarray both in terms of foreign policy and domestic economics at his inauguration that no politician would truly wish to have the responsibility of correcting.
Well said. The nature of the former Mayor's comments are what I would typically call "Un American" at a time when our President is assembling the largest world coalition against terrorism.

Years from now, when this era fades into history, President Obama will be remembered as the leader of the free world, someone who presided over the recovery of one of the nation's worst-ever economic disasters, who presided over eight years of relative peace (compared to the previous eight, anyway), and who chose to build bridges to other cultures rather than preach the kind of fake, simple-minded patriotism preferred by so many of his enemies.
Meanwhile, Rudolph Giuliani will be a minor footnote, just another ex-mayor of NYC who tried and failed to become something bigger, then turned bitter about it.

Republican presidential hopefuls like Jindahl and Scott must somehow think that Guiliani's disparaging comments about President Obama having the makings of a winning GOP strategy in 2016 - throwing as much diversionary dirt as possible at prominent Democrats, especially Obama. After all, look at what Senator McCain's defense of Obama's bonafides did for his presidential aspirations.
I didn't consider Rudy Giuliani a hero after the events of September 11, 2001.  I'm only sorry that so much of America's dimiwtted media did.

Crime went down all over the nation at that time in history. How'd your brave Rudy manage to do that?
Funny how the man who "couldn't be scared off" lacked the spine to tell his wife he was leaving her and the kids. Your selective memory is informed more by the hype than the facts.
https://emcphd.wordpress.com

Your re-phrasal of what I said makes little sense. Just as I can recommend that the United States intensify its fight against cancer without either having cancer being a cancer researcher myself, so too can I or any American recommend that we fight the cancer of Islamism without personally fighting it himself. If the United States adopts a coherent strategy against Islamic terrorism, whoever is capable of helping can (and should) help in whatever way he or she can. I have no children of military age. But if you do, it would be good if they would go and fight Muslim extremism.

@Gretchen Trupiano: Americans who wish to go to Mars in the near future realize that the only thing that might be possible is a one-way trip. Wish is to say they want to escape this country (and this planet), not glorify it.  As for America's official space program, please let us all know how we can afford to revisit it at this juncture or in the foreseeable future.

@Seymour: Thank you for recommending that MY kids volunteer to fight YOUR war.  We'll pass.  In any case, what's your idea of a coherent strategy?  And you don't have to be a political or a military leader to propose one.  (Personally, I'm all for engaging them militarily provided we're talking about a U.N.-authorized mission that would also include troops from Iran, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Jordan (i.e., the countries most directly endangered by ISIS) as well as India, Pakistan, Russia and China (all of which have more reason to be threatened by those people than we do).

I agree with Giuliani. Obama has been very hostile to American interests. He bends over backwards to avoid offending the Muslim extremists who seek to destroy us. He allowed ISIS to grow to its present strength and he opposes effective measures to deal with it even now. It is no wonder that many Americans question which side he is on. I applaud Giuliani for calling him out.
What was racist about his comments?
As Samuel Johnson said: "Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel."
Character=Destiny
He was not convicted - let alone charged - with sexual assault. He's probably no boy scout but good lord please stop saying he sexually assaulted or raped anyone.

The Tallahassee police department didn't find enough to even arrest him or file charges. The FSU investigation -- led by a former state supreme court justice -- cleared him. Why is everyone calling the man a rapist? If the roles were reversed would you be calling the accuser a liar?
Wow! Well stated. It's cruel but Giuliani deserves every word.

What a disgrace Rudy has become. He mocks the way Obama was raised by a grandfather who as a combat veteran,landed on Normandy Beach, and a single mother who worked hard to attain a PhD, prior to dying young from ovarian cancer. Insulting someone's  deceased parent like that is beyond the pale, especially in light of Rudy's own upbringing. Apparently, his own father Harold Guliani raised his only son to be a God-fearing true American who loves his country. How quaint, that by word or example, this violent thug who spent his  career as an enforcer for the mob breaking arms, legs, and worse, was simeotaneosly raising his dear Rudy to love America. Earning his stripes by holding a gun to the head of the family's milkman, for which he spent 18 mos. in Sing Sing, Harold sounds like a true American success story. As a young parent myself, I wish Rudy would share some of dad's child-rearing secrets with us, instead of bashing others. By the way, last time I heard,  Rudy and his own son had not spoken in a very long time.  Any change on that front?
PSY is what I typed. Poor proofing.

Ms. North,

You have written an interesting piece. I work in this field & agree with the National Research Council's position on albedo modification. In geologic history major volcanic events that filled the atmosphere with gasses caused 4 out of the last 5 mass extinctions, the other was caused by a meteoroid.

Many comments seem to recognize that taking action to reduce sunlight would be very risky but there is also a concern that we are taking a risk with global warming gas emissions and reduction of GW gases should be the global priority. The risk of runaway warming emissions from the permafrost & deep ocean methane deposits is real.

Those who have been thinking through the problem of how do we evolve the planet away from combustion of fossil fuels so that the Earth's natural sinks can catch up, have seen that we must replace fossil fuel production of electricity and stop using internal combustion engines for travel & freight hauling.

Drs. James Powell & Gordon Danby, two distinguished scientists at Brookhaven National Lab, invented superconducting magnetic levitation (Maglev) and they were rediscovered by the late Senator Pat Moynihan of NY, who invited them to testify about their system in 1987, where I met them. Mr. Moynihan was concerned about the developing Maglev technology race & put forth an idea of Senator Harry Reid to use Interstate R O W for a National Maglev Network. His committee recommended a R&D program but were opposed by transport interests.

Lisa: That is exactly the point. This is not meant as an offense against preschool teachers and care-givers but they are not trained that well. The pay is low, so mostly you're getting very inexperienced younger adults assuming the roles. They do their best but like in anything else some are better at it than others. Would that we, as a society, recognize that certain jobs, certain roles, have paramount value and pay and train them accordingly. I can think of few jobs more paramount than the role taken on by some to educate and "set straight the feet" of the future by working with preschoolers.

John
American Net'Zen

I agree that young kids who are acting out should have someone who can spend time with them, privately, to empathize and find out what's going on for the child. To expect a classroom teacher to do that, while also programming a day for the other 20+ students (and attending to their individual needs), opening milk cartons and tying shoes, etc., is asking too much. We either need more teachers in classrooms with young children, or support professionals who can focus more directly on mental health needs.

I am amazed that most of the comments that have a lack of compassion for children who have gone through some traumatic incidences in their very young lives. I did not get the impression that preschool teachers were being to told to ignore and allow bad behavior to continue. But instead to work with the child to find the root of the problem. Children don't and can't come out and say what is exactly upsetting them especially if they don't fully comprehend what is going on.

What I got from this article is that our preschool teachers (teachers in general) are not trained properly to work with young children. Because whether or not the child comes from an affluent or poor home he or she does not have the ability to voice what they are feeling, it is up to us adults to do our best to understand and show compassion.

Giuliani's vile remarks were nothing more than the same hateful racism we have seen from the right wing these last six years. The "othering" of Obama through the whole pathetic "birther" nonsense was clear to anyone with a brain. That ugly bit of racism was engaged in by national politicians and leaders, all giving it a wink and a nod, and unwilling to declare the hateful bit of propaganda it was.

And now we have Giuliani engaging in the same tactic: Obama isn't like "US" – he isn't one of "US" – he doesn't "love America" like "US." There is only one, and exactly one excuse for Giuliani's behavior: he is suffering from some onset of dementia and it is manifesting as racism and hate. Otherwise, he is just another right wing bigot who should be shunned.

I used to be a such a fan of the good mayor, but of late he has simply turned into a grumpy old white man in the Republican Party, reminiscent of the good senator from Arizona. His comments, and the lack comments lambasting them from others hopeful of the 2016 GOP ticket, are yet another reason I switched party membership years ago.
I so appreciate the intelligence and reason the current administration has and hold in contempt the oozings from those on the far right, and I applaud the piece the Daily News ran yesterday putting in perspective GIuliani's "love" and how he was raised in sharp contrast to President Obama.

Yes, Rudy Giuliani's independence from office or future runs frees him to dog-whistle without  the accountability held for an official, current or prospective.  Disputing that President Obama loves America or is even like other citizens is a cynical way to rev up the illogical hatred of that man within some Republicans.  And people will keep reaching into their wallets to express their distaste for a leader who is already near the end of his Presidency.

The more you get to know Rudy the less likeable he is. When was hoping to be the GOP candidate for president in 2007 he based his campaign heavily on winning Florida where he spent most of his money and time. The more time he spent there the lower his poll numbers went.  Even Floridians get it right occasionally.

Giuliani was a self-promoter even when he was in charge of the Southern District.  He had Wall Streeters arrested in their offices, after notifying the press, so they could be photographed being led out in handcuffs.  The charges on all but a very few were inevitably dropped quietly.
Rudy Giuliani once again displays the deep insight and nuanced intelligence that made him such a dogged prosecuting attorney. Oh, wait. That WAS deep insight and nuanced intelligence....wasn't it?

Yes! The graph on the left which shows the Share of women on corporate boards by country indicates the US has a mere 19.2%. The author touts the S&P's 19.2% as though this is the number the Chinese should be chasing. Sure, this number is better than 9 or 0% but it's still a long way from half the population...

The parallels between east and west are striking. Like it or not, there is still, to this day, a double standard for women in all walks of life in the US.  Do we have a post sexist society? Not yet...

Truly pathetic. While there have been presidents that I didn't agree with, I respected them  in the most important of offices. His comment that Obama doesn't love his country is bizarre, absurd. So sad.  What limited remaining respect I had for him is gone.
Publicly using one's right of free speech sometimes results in utterances best reserved for one's private thoughts.    It might be better if everyone did not know how you think.
